title: PinMode Inconsistencies across Platforms
body:
**Problem:** Not every platform supports the same PinModes. Specifically, the inconsistent modes are PullDown, OpenDrain, and Repeater. The ‚ÄúRepeater‚Äù mode is available on a few LPC platforms. If a library sets a pin to use one of these inconsistent modes and it is not supported on a target platform, then the compilation will fail.

The current way around this problem is to use a bunch "#if defined" statements to check the platform at compile time. You can see an example of this here:
http://developer.mbed.org/forum/bugs-suggestions/topic/4968/?page=1#comment-27302

As you can see, this is messy and not scalable as we add more platforms.
As we move closer to start using yotta full time, we'll need to stop using the "#if defined" statements in the module code. This is stated in the yotta documentation here: http://docs.yottabuild.org/tutorial/reuse.html 

**Proposed Solution:** Provide a way for the program to determine if a PinMode is supported at runtime. It can take alternate actions if a certain pin isn‚Äôt supported.

This will make significant changes to the existing API, so these changes should be carefully considered.

**Breaking Code Changes**
Currently, the PinMode enum is defined on a platform-by-platform basis. This enum will need to be removed from the platform-specific implementation and moved into the global scope with all possible modes enumerated. The options include:
- PullNone
- PullUp
- PullDown
- OpenDrain
- Repeater

This will remove the issue of compilation issues as all modes will always be in the global namespace. But these do not provide the necessary platform-specific implementation.

A new array will be defined in the platform-specific implementation. This has a specific order detailed below:

```
int PinModes = {
    0,      // PullNone bitmask
    2,      // PullUp bitmask
    -1,     // PullDown not supported, so -1 value
    4,      // OpenDrain bitmask
    -1      //  Repeater not supported, so -1 value
};
```

The order detailed above matches the indices of the PinMode enum, so order is important.

A constant value for PullDefault will also need to be added:

```
const PinMode PullDefault = PullNone;
```

Lastly, all target HAL implementations would need to take these changes into account. Every implementation would have to be changed. The changes would be straightforward to implement, but it will take time.

**Non-Breaking Code Changes**
A function should be added to the GPIO API, The function would be located in gpio_api.h of the hal and it would be declared like this:

```
bool gpio_mode_supported(gpio_t *obj, PinMode mode);
```

title: Pinmap functions don't allow multiple entries per pin
body: The current implementation of the pinmap functions in [pinmap_common.c](https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/blob/master/libraries/mbed/common/pinmap_common.c) don't allow multiple pinmap entries for the same pin. This is a particular problem for targets like the STM32F411, in which some of the pins may be mapped to more than one instance of a particular peripheral. For example, _PB_5_ can be mapped to either _SPI_1_, or _SPI_3_, but the pinmap only supports _SPI_3_. This limits design flexibility since using the "hidden" pin combinations requires switching to the _mbed-src_ library, and manually editing the pinmap.

title: STM32: Fix HSE/HSI clk source detection
body:
When using online compiler (Keil), SystemInit (and systick stuff) are called
before RW  data is initialized, so static and global variables contains
garbage. AHBPrescTable was one of these, used to set a (messed up) systick timeout for HSE to get ready.If it gets ready, no problem, that's why nucleo boards using HSE go straight.
SystemCoreClock variable is affected too, but situation has been already fixed:
- re-set value in Systeminit()
- code jumps to Keil C runtime library which populates RW area, so seting SystemCoreClock variable to its initialized value (uint32_t SystemCoreClock = 16000000;)
- redo hall init does update SytemCoreclock variable

I posted some more info here
http://developer.mbed.org/forum/bugs-suggestions/topic/5600/

Also ported the LSE longer timeout fix to other few platforms.

title: Implement some CAN modes for the LPC1549/LPC11Cxx/LPC1768
body:
I've partially implemented the can_mode HAL functions for the LPC1549/LPC11Cxx and LPC1768 platforms.

On the LPC1549/LPC11Cxx which use the C_CAN controller, I've implemented everything except for GlobalTest mode. On the LPC1768, I implemented everything except for GlobalTest mode and SilentTest mode. Based on my preliminary testing, I'm not sure if it's possible to do SilentTest mode, but it's not entirely obvious what is required of SilentTest mode. Is there official API documentation describing what the behavior is expected for each mode?

As LocalTest mode is substantially new, I've added an automated test case, MBED_A27, which does a simple loopback test that verifies it sees the messages it sends out. It only requires that a CAN transceiver is wired up to the controller with appropriate termination resistors.

I've tested the code against the LPC1549Xpresso and mbed-LPC1768 using GCC_ARM to build the tests.

title: Changed CircBuffer to take its size as a template parameters for efficientcy.
body:
This results in smaller code size and less ram usage because the optimizer knows the size at compile time and it does not need to be stored in ram. It should also be faster because there is no indirection to the heap.

I have not tested this code!

title: mbed/libraries/USBDevice/USBSerial/CircBuffer.h should get its size as a template parameter
body:
template<typename T>
CircBuffer 
seems to only be used in the USBSerial library where its size is set at compile time (in the USBSerial class constructor). If it were rewritten to take its size as a compile time parameter 

template<typename T, int Size>
CircBuffer

the code would be much more efficient in terms of flash size, execution speed and ram footprint.

title: Use the safe bool ideom instead of providing operator bool

We should use the [safe bool ideom](http://www.artima.com/cppsource/safebool.html) instead of defining operator bool, as operator bool allows an implicit conversion to int, which can cause unexpected behaviour.

title: Continuous Integration Features
body:
This pull request adds some features that are useful for integrating our build system with Continuous Integration tools. These features include:
- Provide a toolchain filter for build_release script to allow for easy compilation on multiple platforms (ex.  IAR is not supported on Linux, so this is not included when building on Linux)
- Create HTML build report specifically for mbed library and tests (templates built with jinja2)
- Reorganize test building by moving the building of required libraries (RTOS, Ethernet, etc) to the up front, before any tests are built. This removes redundancy and improves reporting.

I have been testing this on my own VMs and everything seems to be running smoothly. Let me know if you have any thoughts on how things have been organized.

title: Tools - Building the mbed library from the copied files
body:
I was told this earlier by @sg- (Sam, please provide additional details) , faced this issue yesterday.

Added one header file to mbed api folder, compiled the mbed library. Later removed the header file from its location, compiled the library with an error. Similar to this - compile a library and inject this to any header file in the build folder for mbed library:

```
#error This header file should be overwritten before compiling
```

And you will see the error present although it was added to the "copied files". If you change the original file, it will get copied. But not the other way around.

This behavior was derived from the constructor implementation since HAL documentation doesn't exist.

Update SPI API documentation for hardware driven SS. Modify all target spi_api.c implementations. spi_init ssel parameter was used incorrectly to determine master/slave mode rather than enable hardware driven SS (seems to be due to legacy copy paste). Remove duplicate copy paste code of initialization in spi_init that is done by constructor (SPI and SPISlave)

title: MTS Dragonfly & mDot - fix for building applications on Windows
body:
Writing to a file immediately after reading a file in python works in Linux, but not Windows.  This is a known issue: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/14279658/mixing-read-and-write-on-python-files-in-windows

Adding an explicit seek(0, 1), which seeks to the current position in the file, allows the write in Windows to succeed.  Add this change to Dragonfly and mDot platforms so applications can be properly built on Windows as well as Linux.

title: USBDevice: fix missing defined check for TARGET_F411RE
body:
Fix USBDevice usage on NUCLEO F411RE boards by adding missing defined(...)
USBSerial was tested and works fine.

title: Vector table must be 256 aligned
body:
The vector table must be 256 aligned to work reliably, it must have been working by accident up to now.  This modification tested on a u-blox c027 board.  Without the change the value of `SCB->VTOR` and the location of `int_table` just before the call to `test_once()` in the second part of the test are as follows:

`SCB->VTOR 0x10000280, int_table 0x100002a0`

...and obviously the test fails.  With the change they are as follows:

`SCB->VTOR 0x10000400, int_table 0x10000400`

...and the test passes.

See issue:

https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/issues/993

title: mbed test script "vtor_reloc" is missing alignment
body:
I've just been trying to get the `vtor_reloc` script to run and have spotted that the vector table is missing the alignment attribute.  The line:

`uint32_t int_table[NUM_VECTORS];`

...should read:

`uint32_t int_table[NUM_VECTORS] __attribute__ ((aligned(256)));`

...for the script to work reliably.  It must have been working by luck up to now.

title: Reliably running host_tests on a u-blox C027 board
body:
Przemek Wirkus's push request from here:

https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/pull/986

...makes it possible to run host_tests on a u-blox C027 board but, even with this change, they are not completely reliable. For instance, running test `MBED_A1` five times gives me:

```
TargetTest::LPC1768::GCC_ARM::MBED_A1::Basic [TIMEOUT] in 20.48 of 10 sec
TargetTest::LPC1768::GCC_ARM::MBED_A1::Basic [TIMEOUT] in 20.49 of 10 sec
TargetTest::LPC1768::GCC_ARM::MBED_A1::Basic [OK] in 1.36 of 20 sec
TargetTest::LPC1768::GCC_ARM::MBED_A1::Basic [OK] in 1.34 of 20 sec
TargetTest::LPC1768::GCC_ARM::MBED_A1::Basic [TIMEOUT] in 20.47 of 10 sec
```

In general I get a timeout about 1/3 of the time. Running with `-v` and looking at a fail case, it says:

```
Executing 'python host_test.py -d D: -f "C:\projects\mbed\build\test\LPC1768\GCC_ARM\MBED_A1\basic.bin" -p COM31 -t 10 -C 1.5 -m LPC1768'
Test::Output::Start
MBED: Instrumentation: "COM31" and disk: "D:"
HOST: Copy image onto target...
HOST: Initialize serial port...
....port ready!
HOST: Reset target...
HOST: Unknown property:
HOST: Unknown property:
HOST: Unknown property:
HTest::Output::Finish
```

The first `Unknown property:` is sometimes followed by `{` or `{{timeout;2.` I've tried adding a 5 second `reset_tout` delay but that doesn't seem to help. Is there a more detailed level of debug I could look at to find out what's going wrong? Watching the C027 board as things run, it's difficult to correlate when the problem occurs with the behaviour of the LEDs, but it is something to do with the end of the copy and the reset I guess. What else could I do to make this reliable?

Hi,

And, We modify some settings as below.
- Increase OS main thread stack size.
  When the user makes a program , it is often continue to add the process to the main thread.
  For this reason, increase main thread stack size.
- Change terminal settings for new GR-PEACH board(board update).

Regards,
Hamanaka

title: [NUCLEO_L152RE] reorg hal
body: no code changes, only new file/path structure similar to STM32L0, STM32F0, STM32F4 structure

title: [HAL][K20XX/KLXX] Fixed deepsleep power consumption when AnalogIn is used
body:
The power consumption was reported by Paul Staron to be 100uA higher
when an AnalogIn was used previously.

Problem 1 is that 40uA was used by the async ADC clock, which is never
actually used, so it is disabled. Problem 2 is that setting it for high
speed mode increased it by another 60uA while in deepsleep. This
currently seems to me to be possibly a bug in the design, but the
workaround is checking if this is the case before going to deepsleep,
and if yes, disable it. Afterwards it is re-enabled.

The KSDK ones have different AnalogIn code, could very well be same issue though.

title: Added timeouts (delays) on serial port and mounting point
body:
# Description
- Added timeouts (delays) on serial port and mounting point accesses in host_test and copy plugins to prevent serial/disk I/O errors when device remounts USB iface of interface chip.
- Also some Freedom boards (KL25Z, KL46Z) can cause re-mounting issues when (experimental) parallel test execution is turn on option `--parallel`.
  This implementation hopefully solves both problems.
  # Rationale
  There was a problem with U-BLOX interface chip which is re-mounting and causing serial / mount point I/O when test suite is executed.
  See here: http://developer.mbed.org/questions/6743/singletestpy-need-wait-between-end-of-co

Fix is adding pooling for serial port and mount point so we are only flashing and reading from serial when both are available (when accessing).
# Usage:

```
$ singletest.py -i test_spec.json -M muts_all.json  --global-loops 3 -W
```

or (only when mbed-ls is installed)

```
$ singletest.py --auto --global-loops 3 -W
```

Note: Flags `--global-loops 3 -W` added to repeat failing tests up to 3 times.

Results:


## (Experimental) Parallel tests for KL25Z and KL46Z fix:

This pull request should also fix parallel execution for few Freedom Boards (its interface chip also behaves in such a way it remounts USB devices after target reset / flashing).

body: Re-organized file layout to match that from the Nordic SDK V7.1. Also updated targets.py to include -DNRF51 for Nordic builds.

body: Nordic has released a few updates to their SDK, of which we can switch to V7.1.0.

title: Using "Data Terminal Ready" signal to determine when the host is connected.
body: It believe it would be better to use the "Data Terminal Ready" signal to determine when the host has connected and can accept characters.

title: Added macros to alias the endpoint callback functions to support configurability
body:
Macros exist in each of the USBEndpoints_<target>.h files for assigning default endpoints for bulk, interrupt and isochronous functions. These macros are used by the various device classes. The callback functions in the classes, however, are hard coded to specific endpoint numbers. I have added additional macros to alias the callback functions to ensure that they match the assigned endpoints for a given target.

All currently supported USBDevice targets have used the same endpoint assignments, so no problem has arisen. We are currently working on adding a new target in which the endpoint assignments will be different from the other targets and encountered this issue.
